newsitem.title: UK: PRESS DIGEST - British business press - Feb 19.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - British business press - Feb 19.

text.p: Prepared for Reuters by The Broadcast Monitoring Company DAILY TELEGRAPH
-- SOROS MAN CONSIDERS BID FOR PLANTATION

The fund manager of George Soros, Nick Roditi is considering making a 58p a share bid for Plantation and General Investments, the company which grows tea, coffee, rubber and timber, as well as making farm tools. The announcement from Roditi's brokers started a 17 percent rise in Plantation's share price to 61.5p. -- MARRIOTT PAYS $1 BILLION FOR RENAISSANCE HOTELS

The US hotels giant, Marriott International, will pay $1 billion for the Renaissance Hotel Group, creating a group which operates or franchises over 1,300 hotels around the world. Analysts claim the deal would pose a threat to Bass, the brewer which runs the Holiday Inn franchises, and put pressure on it to make acquisitions.
-- STERLING WILTS AS RATE FEARS RECEDE

The softening of the Bank of England's line over interest rates and a better-than-expected government borrowing figures provided the signal for sterling to lose ground yesterday as foreign exchange markets decided that an interest rate rise was not imminent. The pound fell over 1.5 cents against the dollar to 1.6015 dollars and lost four pfennigs against the German mark to Dm2.7087. The trade index fell 1.2 percent to 96.8.
THE TIMES
-- GRANADA SELLS 566 MILLION STG OF FORTE ASSETS

Granada Group yesterday continued the sale of former Forte assets disposing of the Welcome Break service station chain and the Westbury hotels in London and New York. The Welcome Break chain was sold for 476 million stg to Bahrain based investment group, Investcorp, and Chelsfield, the property company paid 90 million stg for the two Westbury hotels.
-- SHARES SLIDE AT BARCLAYS IN SPITE OF 2.4 BLN STG PROFIT

Barclays share price fell yesterday despite the news of a 13 percent rise in full-year profits to 2.4 billion stg and a pledge from Barclays to return 500 million stg to shareholders during the coming year. The share price fell to 1129 pence, down 70.5p on the ground that the figures were at the lower end of the market expectations combined with a sharper than predicted drop in operation profits at BZW, the global investment banking arm of Barclays.
-- CLARKE WELCOMES TAX AND DEBT FIGURES

The latest figures from the Office for National Statistics shows a sharp improvement in Britain's public finances has been reported in January, with a bumper haul of corporation tax and VAT receipts. The Government repaid 5.82 billion stg of borrowing in January, almost twice as much as the City had predicted. Kenneth Clarke, the Chancellor said the figures were excellent and offered further confirmation that borrowing is on a clear downward path.
THE GUARDIAN -- WINDFALL OF 200 STG FOR BRITANNIC'S LUCKY ONE MILLION

Over a million Britannic Assurance policyholders will benefit from windfall bonuses of an average of 200 stg following the identification of surplus assets in the insurer's life fund. The bonuses will be paid to about 1.2 million with-profits policy holders when their policies mature.
-- DEUTSCHE BANK PROFITS ARE HIT BY YOUNG SCANDAL

Deutsche, Germany's biggest bank revealed modest profits yesterday, despite a sharp rise in new business. After tax and special items, profits were only 5 percent up at 2.2 billion marks for 1996, while operating profits were up by 38 percent. The difference has been put down to the price of compensation for Morgan Grenfell investors following the Peter Young scandal, which has so far cost Deutsche one billion marks
-- DRUGS FIRMS JOIN POUND WARNING

Glaxo Wellcome and SmithKline Beecham, the drugs companies, yesterday joined other British companies in predicting that profits could be hit substantially if the pound remains at its current strong levels. The negative effect of the strong pound to British exports will be underlined by tomorrow's Confederation of British Industry industrial trends survey.
THE INDEPENDENT
-- GULF WINS BID BATTLE FOR CLYDE PETROLEUM

The decision by Norwich Union to accept Gulf Canada's 120p a share offer for its eight percent stake in Clyde Petroleum sealed the British oil explorer's fate yesterday. Gulf secured 51.4 percent of Clyde's shares thus ending one of the most bitterly fought of recent hostile bids. Roy Franklin, Clyde's chief executive is expected to asked to remain with the company.
-- SHANDWICK SHARES SUFFER AS DIRECTORS DEFECT TO SET UP RIVAL

Shandwick International, the public relations group, suffered a fall in shares of 12 percent yesterday following the defection of five of its most senior staff to set up a rival agency. Shares recovered later in the day after it emerged that the split was not as big as many had feared. The new agency is expected to be launched on 1 April and will be named the Hogarth Partnership.
-- RESHUFFLE TO LET PEPTIDE TARGET US

The biotechnology group, Peptide Therapeutics, is to reshuffle its top management team only 15 months after coming to the market. The main movers are finance director, John Brown who will become chief executive, while outgoing chief executive, Alan Goodman will become deputy chairman. The news follows Peptides announcement of losses for the year to December of 4.59 million stg.
